questions.text: A 16-year-old female with cystic fibrosis presents with increased productive cough, fever, and worsening shortness of breath. Her sputum culture grows Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Which of the following best explains why this organism commonly causes respiratory infections in cystic fibrosis patients?

options.label: A
options.text: Defective neutrophil chemotaxis to the site of infection

options.label: B
options.text: Abnormal periciliary fluid layer leading to impaired mucociliary clearance

options.label: C
options.text: Direct immunosuppressive effect of the CFTR protein mutation

options.label: D
options.text: Increased expression of bacterial adhesion molecules on respiratory epithelium

questions.correct_answer: B. Abnormal periciliary fluid layer leading to impaired mucociliary clearance
questions.explanation:
Mechanism

Key Features

CFTR Defect
  •  Defective chloride/bicarbonate transport
  •  Located in apical plasma membranes
  •  F508del (phenylalanine is replaced) mutation most common (~70%)

Airway Changes
  •  Depleted periciliary fluid layer
  •  Thick mucus accumulation
  •  Impaired mucociliary clearance

Infection Risk
  •  Common pathogens: P. aeruginosa, S. aureus
  •  Chronic bacterial colonization
  •  Progressive bronchiectasis

Clinical Impact
  •  Recurrent pneumonia
  •  Progressive lung damage
  •  Requires aggressive antibiotic therapy

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant presents with failure to thrive, recurrent respiratory infections, and elevated sweat chloride. Genetic testing reveals two copies of the F508del mutation in the CFTR gene. This mutation results in a protein that fails to reach the cell surface due to degradation in the endoplasmic reticulum. Which class of CFTR mutation does this represent, and what percentage of CF patients carry at least one copy of this mutation?
questions.correct_answer: B. Class II mutation; ~70% of patients
questions.explanation:
Mutation Class

Severity

Protein Effect

Clinical Impact

Class I & II

(Option A)

Severe

No functional protein or severe processing defect

Pancreatic insufficiency, severe lung disease

Class III & IV

(Option C, D)

Moderate

Defective channel function or conductance

Variable pancreatic status, moderate lung disease

Class V

Mild to Moderate

Reduced amount of normal protein

Lower incidence of pancreatic insufficiency compared to class I and II, milder lung disease

Class VI

Variable

Decreased protein stability

Variable severity based on protein turnover rate

Organ System

Pathological Features

Clinical Manifestations

Diagnostic Findings

Respiratory
  • Thick mucus plugging
  • Bronchiectasis
  • Chronic inflammation
  • Submucosal gland hypertrophy
  • Chronic productive cough
  • Recurrent infections
  • Progressive dyspnea
  • Digital clubbing
  • P. aeruginosa in sputum
  • Obstructive pattern on PFTs
  • Bronchiectasis on CT

Pancreatic
  • Duct obstruction
  • Acinar cell destruction
  • Fibrosis
  • Fat replacement
  • Malabsorption
  • Steatorrhea
  • Failure to thrive
  • Fat-soluble vitamin deficiency
  • Low fecal elastase
  • Elevated fecal fat
  • Low vitamins A, D, E, K

Sweat Glands
  • Abnormal chloride transport
  • Normal gland structure
  • Salty-tasting skin
  • Heat intolerance
  • Salt depletion
  • Elevated sweat chloride
  • >60 mEq/L diagnostic

Hepatobiliary
  • Bile duct plugging
  • Focal biliary cirrhosis
  • Multilobular cirrhosis
  • Neonatal cholestasis
  • Portal hypertension
  • Gallstones
  • Elevated liver enzymes
  • Ultrasound changes

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy comes to the emergency department with difficulty breathing and a productive cough. He has a history of recurrent sinusitis and otitis media and usually responds well to antibiotics. Crackles and wheezing are heard on pulmonary auscultation and CVS examination shows the cardiac point of maximum impulse on the right 5th intercostal space. Which of them is not seen in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Features

Kartagener's Syndrome

Cystic Fibrosis

Diagnostic Triad
  • Situs inversus
  • Recurrent sinusitis
  • Recurrent pneumonia
  • Chronic cough
  • Steatorrhea
  • Failure to thrive

Molecular Defect

Dynein protein defect (Option A)

CFTR mutation

Primary Problem

Defective mucociliary clearance (Option D)

Abnormal chloride transport

Key Features
  • Male infertility
  • Situs inversus
  • Normal sweat chloride (Option B)
  • Elevated sweat chloride
  • Male and female infertility
  • Pancreatic insufficiency
  • Normal organ placement

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with a chronic productive cough, nasal polyps, and poor weight gain despite normal appetite. Which of the following is the most likely associated condition?
questions.explanation:
System

Manifestations

Respiratory System:
Due to defective chloride channels, airway mucus becomes dehydrated and highly viscous.
  • Airway Obstruction: Thickened mucus obstructs the airways, making it difficult to clear, trapping pathogens, and leading to frequent infections.
  • Chronic Infections: CF patients harbour chronic infections with Staphylococcus aureus, Haemophilus influenzae, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Over time, Pseudomonas evolves into a mucoid form that is highly resistant to treatment and worsens prognosis.
  • Inflammation and Bronchiectasis: Persistent infection leads to chronic neutrophilic inflammation, damaging airway tissue and causing bronchiectasis (permanent airway dilation). This inflammatory response further exacerbates mucus accumulation and infection.

Pancreas:
CFTR dysfunction leads to blockage of pancreatic ducts by thickened secretions.
  • Exocrine Pancreatic Insufficiency: The ducts become obstructed, preventing digestive enzymes from reaching the intestines, leading to malabsorption, steatorrhea (fatty stools), and poor weight gain.
  • Endocrine Dysfunction: Over time, recurrent inflammation and fibrosis damage pancreatic islets, increasing the risk of CF-related diabetes mellitus (CFRD), a common complication in adults with CF.

Gastrointestinal Tract:
Thick mucus impacts various parts of the gastrointestinal system.
  • Meconium Ileus in Newborns: Nearly 10-20% of newborns with CF present with meconium ileus, an intestinal obstruction that can be life-threatening without surgical intervention.
  • Distal Intestinal Obstructive Syndrome (DIOS): Older children and adults may experience DIOS, where thickened intestinal contents obstruct the lower intestines.

Liver
  • CF can lead to biliary cirrhosis due to mucus plugging in bile ducts. Approximately 5-10% of patients develop multilobular cirrhosis, which may progress to portal hypertension and liver failure.

Reproductive System
  • Male Infertility: Males with CF will have a congenital bilateral absence of the vas deferens (CBAVD), leading to infertility despite normal spermatogenesis.
  • Female Infertility: Females with CF may also face reduced fertility due to thick cervical mucus that hinders sperm penetration.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant presents with recurrent respiratory infections and failure to thrive. Physical examination reveals digital clubbing and productive cough. A sweat test shows elevated chloride levels, but the genotype analysis for common CFTR mutations is inconclusive. Which of the following investigations is the next best step for confirming the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis in this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Genetic panel including rare CFTR mutations

questions.text: A newborn screening for CF shows elevated immunoreactive trypsinogen (IRT) levels. What is the next best step in the diagnostic process?

options.label: A
options.text: Repeat the IRT test in 6 months

questions.correct_answer: B. Genetic testing for CFTR mutations

questions.text: Which of the following therapies directly targets the basic molecular defect in cystic fibrosis for a patient with a G551D mutation?
questions.explanation:
CFTR Modulators:

Target the root cause of CF in patients with specific mutations.
  • Ivacaftor: A potentiator for gating mutations like G551D, enhancing chloride transport by improving CFTR channel opening. (Option C)
  • Lumacaftor and Tezacaftor: Correctors that aid CFTR protein folding and trafficking, effective for F508del homozygous patients when combined with ivacaftor.
  • Elexacaftor-Tezacaftor-Ivacaftor (Trikafta):
    • A triple-combination therapy approved for patients with at least one F508del mutation.
    • This combination substantially improves lung function, nutritional status, and quality of life.

Pulmonary Therapy:

For improving mucus clearance and managing chronic infections.
  • Airway Clearance Techniques (ACTs): Chest physiotherapy, high-frequency chest wall oscillation, and oscillating positive expiratory pressure (PEP) devices help mobilize and clear thick mucus.
  • Nebulized Medications:
    • Hypertonic saline and recombinant human DNase (dornase alfa) thin mucus and enhance clearance.
    • Inhaled antibiotics (e.g., tobramycin) are used for chronic Pseudomonas infections.
  • Anti-inflammatory Agents: Azithromycin is used for intense inflammation in CF lungs for its anti-inflammatory properties.

Digestive Support:
  • Pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy for managing pancreatic insufficiency. Enzyme supplements improve digestion and nutrient absorption.
  • Fat-soluble vitamin supplementation (A, D, E, K) to prevent deficiencies.
  • High-calorie, high-protein diet: to maintain adequate growth and body weight.

CF Complications:
  • CF-related Diabetes (CFRD): Managed with insulin, as oral hypoglycemic agents are generally ineffective.
  • Liver Disease: Ursodeoxycholic acid can be used to manage biliary complications.
  • End-stage Lung Disease: Lung transplantation is an option for advanced disease with respiratory failure. Median survival post-transplant is over 9 years.

questions.text: A 45-year-old obese male (BMI- 40) presents with complaints of loud snoring and daytime sleepiness. His wife reports that he complains of disturbed sleep due to waking up out of breath because of an obstruction of the airway. Polysomnography reveals repetitive episodes showing: Sharp inspiratory uptake Flattened/plateau wave Scooped out breathing pattern Flow limitation Oxygen desaturation What is the correct sequence of pathophysiologic events leading to his symptoms?

options.label: A
options.text: REM sleep → Hypoxia → Pharyngeal dilator muscle relaxation → Airway narrowing → snoring

options.label: B
options.text: Pharyngeal dilator muscle relaxation → Airway narrowing → Flow limitation → Hypoxia → Cortical arousal

options.label: C
options.text: Obesity → Flow limitation → Airway collapse → Snoring → Bradycardia → Hypoxia

options.label: D
options.text: Hypoxia → Airway collapse → Flow limitation → Bradycardia → Cortical arousal

questions.correct_answer: B. Pharyngeal dilator muscle relaxation → Airway narrowing → Flow limitation → Hypoxia → Cortical arousal

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with complaints of daytime sleepiness and morning headaches, and his wife reports loud snoring with episodes of gasping during sleep. His BMI is 32 kg/m², neck circumference is 44 cm, and he has retrognathia. His blood pressure is 148/92 mmHg. Which of the following combinations of additional clinical features and diagnostic findings would not be seen with obstructive sleep apnea in this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Central obesity, elevated sweat chloride, pancreatic insufficiency

questions.correct_answer: B. Central obesity, elevated sweat chloride, pancreatic insufficiency
questions.explanation:
Category

Clinical Features

Nocturnal Symptoms
  • Loud snoring
  • Witnessed apneas
  • Gasping/choking episodes
  • Frequent awakenings

Daytime Symptoms
  • Excessive daytime sleepiness
  • Morning headaches
  • Difficulty concentrating
  • Irritability

Physical Findings
  • Obesity (especially central)
  • Large neck circumference
  • Retrognathia
  • Hypertension

Diagnostic Findings
  • Fragmented sleep on PSG
  • Frequent arousals
  • Oxygen desaturation
  • Nondipping blood pressure pattern

PSG Parameter

Typical OSA Findings

Clinical Significance

Respiratory Events
  • Cessation of airflow ≥10 seconds
  • Continued chest/abdominal effort
  • AHI 5-14 (mild), 15-29 (moderate), ≥30 (severe)
  • Indicates upper airway obstruction with continued respiratory effort

Oxygen Saturation
  • Intermittent desaturations ≥3% Cycling pattern with events
  • May see significant drops
  • Reflects severity and potential cardiovascular impact

Sleep Architecture
  • Increased light sleep (N1)
  • Reduced deep sleep (N3)
  • Reduced REM sleep
  • Fragmented sleep pattern
  • Indicates sleep disruption and poor sleep quality

Arousals
  • Frequent cortical arousals
  • Event-related arousals
  • Increased arousal index
  • Leads to sleep fragmentation and daytime symptoms

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding risk factors of Obstructive Sleep Apnea?

options.label: A
options.text: Premenopausal women have the same risk for OSA as postmenopausal women

options.label: B
options.text: A 10% increase in body weight is associated with a >30% increase in apnea-hypopnea index (AHI)

options.label: C
options.text: Approximately 40-60% of OSA cases are attributable to excess body weight

options.label: D
options.text: Men have approximately twice the risk of developing OSA compared to women

questions.correct_answer: A. Premenopausal women have the same risk for OSA as postmenopausal women
questions.explanation:
Category

Risk Factors

Clinical Impact

Demographic
  • Male gender
  • Older age
  • Post-menopausal status
  • Family history
  • Men have 2x higher risk (Option D)
  • Risk increases with age
  • Hormonal protection in premenopausal women

Anatomical
  • Retrognathia/micrognathia
  • Increased neck circumference (>40cm in women, >43cm in men)
  • Nasal obstruction
  • Enlarged tonsils
  • Affects airway patency
  • Increases collapsibility
  • Reduces airway diameter

Body Composition
  • Obesity (BMI >30)
  • Central adiposity
  • Weight gain
  • Large waist circumference
  • 40-60% of OSA attributable to excess weight (Option C)
  • 10% weight gain increases AHI by >30% (Option B)

Medical Conditions
  • Endocrine disorders (hypothyroidism, acromegaly)
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Hypertension
  • Down syndrome
  • Increases susceptibility
  • May affect treatment response
  • Bidirectional relationship

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with complaints of excessive daytime sleepiness and his spouse reports loud snoring with disturbed sleep due to breathing pauses during sleep. His BMI is 34 kg/m² and neck circumference is 43 cm. Which of the following should be the INITIAL step in evaluating this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Start CPAP therapy based on symptoms

options.label: C
options.text: Obtain detailed sleep history with standardized sleepiness questionnaires and perform focused physical examination

questions.correct_answer: C. Obtain detailed sleep history with standardized sleepiness questionnaires and perform focused physical examination
questions.explanation:
Diagnostic Step

Key Components

Clinical Significance

Initial Evaluation
  • Detailed sleep history
  • Bed partner history
  • Epworth Sleepiness Scale
  • Screening questionnaires
  • Assess symptom severity
  • Document witnessed events
  • Quantify daytime sleepiness
  • Screen for risk factors

Physical Examination
  • BMI and neck circumference
  • Upper airway examination
  • Jaw structure assessment
  • Nasal examination
  • Cardiovascular evaluation
  • Identify anatomic risk factors
  • Assess for complications
  • Guide treatment options
  • Screen for comorbidities

Sleep Study Options
  • In-lab polysomnography (PSG)
  • Home sleep testing (HST)
  • Split-night study if indicated
  • Gold standard & IOC: PSG
  • HST for selected patients
  • Quantify disease severity
  • Guide treatment decisions

Additional Testing
  • ECG/cardiac evaluation
  • Blood pressure monitoring
  • Metabolic screening
  • Cognitive/alertness testing
  • Assess complications
  • Monitor comorbidities
  • Guide comprehensive management
  • Evaluate impairment

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is diagnosed with moderate obstructive sleep apnea (AHI=22/hour) based on polysomnography. He has daytime sleepiness, BMI of 35 kg/m², and hypertension. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment approach for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Prescribe oral appliance therapy as first-line treatment

options.label: B
options.text: Initiate CPAP therapy with appropriate pressure titration and provide supportive care

options.label: C
options.text: Recommend uvulopalatopharyngoplasty without trying conservative measures

questions.correct_answer: B. Initiate CPAP therapy with appropriate pressure titration and provide supportive care
questions.explanation:
Treatment Option

Indications/Features

Advantages/Limitations

CPAP Therapy
  • First-line therapy & Gold standard
  • All severity levels
  • Requires titration study
  • Regular monitoring needed
  • Most effective option
  • Reversible/non-invasive
  • Insurance covered
  • Adherence challenges

Lifestyle Modifications and weight loss

(Option D)
  • Weight loss
  • Sleep position therapy
  • Alcohol avoidance
  • Sleep hygiene
  • Adjunctive to primary therapy
  • Long-term benefits
  • No immediate relief
  • Variable results

Oral Appliances

(Option A)
  • Mild to moderate OSA
  • CPAP intolerance
  • Good dental health
  • Normal TMJ
  • More comfortable than CPAP
  • Portable
  • Less effective than CPAP
  • Dental side effects

Surgical Options

(Option C)
  • Specific anatomic defects
  • Failed conservative therapy
  • Carefully selected patients
  • Bariatric surgery for obesity
  • Permanent solution
  • No ongoing compliance needed
  • Invasive
  • Variable success rates

questions.text: A 45-year-old male reports persistent daytime sleepiness, often dozing off during meetings and while watching television. He completes the Epworth Sleepiness Scale (ESS) and scores 12. What does a score of 12 indicate?

options.label: C
options.text: Possibly excessively sleepy; consider medical attention.

options.label: D
options.text: Excessively sleepy; seek immediate medical attention.

questions.correct_answer: C. Possibly excessively sleepy; consider medical attention.
questions.explanation:
Situation

No Chance (0)

Slight Chance (1)

Moderate Chance (2)

High Chance (3)

Sitting and reading

No chance of dozing = 0

Slight chance of dozing = 1

Moderate chance of dozing = 2

High chance of dozing = 3

Watching television

Sitting inactive in a public space

Lying down to rest in the afternoon when permitted

Sitting and talking to someone

Sitting quietly after lunch without alcohol

As a passenger in a car for an hour without a break

In a car, while stopped for a few minutes in traffic

Total Score:

0 to 24

questions.text: A 52-year-old obese male presents to the clinic with excessive daytime sleepiness hypoventilation and difficulty breathing at night. His BMI is 32 kg/m², and arterial blood gas analysis shows a Paco2 of 48 mmHg recorded during the day. The patient reports loud snoring and episodes of gasping during sleep. He has a history of severe obesity and is suspected of having obstructive sleep apnea. Based on the scenario, which of the following diagnoses is most likely?

A 25-year-old tall male presents to the emergency department with acute retrosternal chest pain and difficulty breathing after a vigorous bout of coughing. He reports having experienced frequent coughing spells over the past week due to a respiratory infection. On physical examination, subcutaneous emphysema is noted in the neck region. The chest X-ray of the patient is given below. Which of the following statements best describes a potential cause of this patient’s condition?

options.label: A
options.text: The condition is likely caused by a foreign body in the airway.

options.label: B
options.text: Increased intra-alveolar pressure from excessive coughing can lead to alveolar rupture.

options.label: C
options.text: This condition is primarily associated with high BMI individuals.

options.label: D
options.text: Always a result of blunt trauma.

questions.correct_answer: B. Increased intra-alveolar pressure from excessive coughing can lead to alveolar rupture.
questions.explanation:
Pneumomediastinum

About
  • Air in the mediastinum (mediastinal emphysema).
  • Air can extravasate from airways, lungs, or esophagus into the mediastinal space and may dissect into cervical subcutaneous tissues, epidural space, pericardium, or peritoneal cavity.
  • Most common in younger males of tall stature with low BMI.
  • Pneumomediastinum is rare and usually self-limited

Etiology
  • Spontaneous (Primary) Pneumomediastinum: No identifiable cause, occurs in healthy individuals.
  • Secondary Pneumomediastinum: Caused by identifiable conditions, trauma being the most common cause (alveolar rupture).
    • Caused by intrinsic lung and airway issues such as asthma, COPD, bronchiectasis, ILD, lung cancer,etc; iatrogenic factors including endoscopy, intubation, central venous access procedures, thoracostomy, and chest or abdominal surgeries; and traumatic events like blunt trauma, penetrating trauma, and blast injuries.

Pathophysiology
  • Macklin Phenomenon: Three-step process of pneumomediastinum development:
    • Increased intra-alveolar pressure leads to alveolar rupture.
    • Air dissects into peribronchial and perivascular sheaths.
    • Air spreads into the mediastinum and surrounding tissue.
  • Causes of increased intra-alveolar pressure: Excessive vomiting, coughing, strenuous exertion, Valsalva maneuvers.
  • Airway diseases (asthma, COPD) predispose to airway injury from increased alveolar pressures.
  • Forceful inhalation during drug use can cause barotrauma and increase pneumomediastinum risk.

Clinical Features
  • Common Symptoms:
    • Retrosternal chest pain (60-100% of patients), often acute and related to excessive coughing/vomiting.
    • Dyspnea (75%).
    • Coughing spells (80%).
    • Neck pain (36%).
    • Odynophagia, dysphagia, emesis, abdominal pain.
  • Common Signs on Physical Exam:
    • Subcutaneous emphysema (70%).
    • Hamman sign: mediastinal crunch synchronous with heart sounds.
    • Rhinolalia (nasal tone of speech), dysphonia, hoarseness, neck swelling, tachycardia, tachypnea.
  • Rare presentation: Malignant pneumomediastinum causing cardiac tamponade physiology.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with chest pain and difficulty breathing after experiencing a severe coughing fit. A chest X-ray is performed and is given below. Which of the following statements is true regarding the management of this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: The primary diagnostic tool for this condition is a CT scan.

options.label: B
options.text: Surgical intervention is always required for treatment.

options.label: C
options.text: Conservative management is usually sufficient for most patients with this condition.

options.label: D
options.text: Prophylactic antibiotics are necessary for all patients diagnosed.

questions.correct_answer: C. Conservative management is usually sufficient for most patients with this condition.
